Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Low Cost Transparent Wireless Mesh Network Node
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Program (SBIR) Phase II project advances antenna technology and wireless network performance by developing a new kind of wireless mesh network node, i.e. integrated router, radio and antenna, and the software necessary to create a network of such devices. Networking is an important productivity resource, but can come at a high cost especially for high-data rates. Dramatic capacity gains in urban wireless networks are achieved by deploying directional antennas to minimize interference and allow substantial frequency reuse. Indoor mounting of nodes in windows is desirable to avoid complications with landlords, avoid weather, and decrease RF path loss. Finally, larger antennas produce more directionality, so the desired wireless node needs a large surface area and yet must be something that people are willing to hang in their windows, i.e. transparent and attractive. This project is using transparent conductive coatings with a novel combination of beam steering and Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) radio technology to develop a mostly transparent wireless node that achieves a <15 degree wide beam that is electronically steerable over >110 degrees.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project includes increased US competitiveness by facilitating the spread of high speed Internet access and through the sale of innovative new devices in the US and worldwide. Community networks will deploy these nodes, as they are the lowest cost and simplest way to create an inter-building network. In particular, delivering signals via windows overcomes RF absorption in the masonry structures typical of public housing projects. Successful commercialization of this technology will significantly reduce the cost and increase the performance of urban wireless networks, thus helping extend Internet access to un- and under-served neighborhoods and reducing the cost of offloading 3G/4G wireless traffic to local Wi-Fi hotspots.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report - NSF SBIR Phase II Award 1353254

This SBIR Phase II project focused on the development of a transparent antenna and its integration into a mostly transparent wireless mesh network node that a consumer could purchase, hang in their window and use to obtain high speed Internet service for their home.

The project turned out to be considerably more difficult than originally envisioned, however our results substantially advanced transparent antenna technology and demonstrated the feasibility of using this technology as originally envisioned.  To construct the antenna we used a new kind of transparent conductive material independently developed for the smartphone touchscreen market. With this material, we found ways to fabricate antenna elements and the radio frequency compatible wiring needed to connect these elements into complete antennas of differing complexity. Our resulting antennas perform nearly as well conventional (opaque) copper-based antennas and considerably better than earlier transparent antennas. Our antennas also provide significantly improved signal-to-interference ratios compared to any other approach that does not require professional aiming.

While we did not succeed in making a complete, mostly transparent, wireless mesh network node as originally envisioned, we did succeed in assembling a laboratory prototype combining three complete transparent antennas with opaque beam steering circuits and an (opaque) commercial Wi-Fi router.  We also assembled four completely opaque equivalents for use as development platforms and to prove we could establish a high performance wireless mesh network. We used these prototypes to develop extensive software including low-level antenna steering control, integration of open source and internally developed higher-level software for a complete wireless mesh network node and the management software that utilizes our novel antennas to form a high-performance wireless mesh.

With these prototypes we demonstrated that the original product concept is still technically viable and set the stage for development of a commercial version.
